posts.name:
Chinmay Patel ‚òÄÔ∏è
Chinmay Patel ‚òÄÔ∏è
posts.content:
"Why are you the best team to build this product" is the best investor question.

If the answer is anything other than below, it's not the right answer

* We have a deep customer insight and/or industry knowledge.

* The product requires this tech -- only a handful of folks know about this. Our team is one of them.

* The founders have a rolodex of clients in this industry.

* We already have a product and early customer validation.

What could be some of the wrong answers?

* Our team is young. We can build anything and we can sell anything.

* Our customers raise money. So, if they can do it, we can do it.

* We have worked with each other in the past. So, we enjoy working together.

This mindset allowed me to raise my seed fund 3 years back, and we're still benefiting from it.

What are your favorite Q&A during fundraising?

posts.name:
Matthew Wohl
Matthew Wohl
posts.content:
Phone interview tip:

If you have a phone interview scheduled at a specific time, answer your phone at that time.

It is highly unlikely you'll receive a spam call at the exact same time as your scheduled interview.

I've spoken to tons of candidates that had to call me back because they didn't recognize my phone number and didn't answer.

That puts us behind schedule and often leaves the candidate feeling rushed.

OP

This happens to me every other day word for word as Denise put it.

comments.commentText:
And the other day, someone called me out of the blue for a technical interview at Tata Consultancy Services . When I said I am busy at the time, they never bothered to reschedule. 

There was no email, no sms, no voicemail prior to this call! Was I expected to drop everything at the moments notice and attend technical? Not sure.

Just saying these are also happening!
The Frustrated Developer That is not what this post is about. It clearly says scheduled interview.
The Frustrated Developer If you are job hunting answer every incoming call. So, yes.
Why do you even use a phone instead of calendar + google meet or whatever?
Serg Sar Because I am interviewing you for your knowledge, not your appearance.

posts.name:
Niharikaa Kaur Sodhi
Niharikaa Kaur Sodhi
posts.content:
My friend's wife wants to quit her high-paying job because there's barely any motivation to grow at work. Her boss works longer hours, why would she want to be there?

Reminds me of this quote by Robert Frost:

"By working faithfully 8 hours a day, you may eventually get to work twelve hours a day".

I used to think it was just me who got demotivated looking at my leaders. Some of them had families and worked weekends too. How is that progress? Why would any junior get motivated to work hard when they see this?

I read this on Reddit somewhere - we are all so overly stressed and anxious because we weren't meant to work this much in today's time.

comments.commentText: Niharikaa, your insights resonate deeply. It‚Äôs disheartening when the path to success appears to be paved with exhaustion rather than inspiration. Leadership should ignite motivation, not act as a deterrent. We need to advocate for a culture that values well-being alongside productivity to truly foster growth in ourselves and others.
Priyank Ahuja A culture of well-being fosters more genuine success and growth.

posts.name:
Keith Tode, MBA
Keith Tode, MBA
posts.content:
LAYOFFS AND WONDERING WHAT MORE YOU CAN DO

How much is enough?

There comes a point in your job search where you reach your breaking point.

You can't even remember how many jobs you've applied to, how many recruiter calls you've had or how many times you've been rejected or ghosted.

You've networked like a rookie politician and have tailored your CV about 743 times with nothing to show for your efforts.

It feels like you're losing your marbles.

No matter what the career coaches or cv writers say, you can do everything, and I do mean everything, correctly and still not get an interview, let alone the job.

It leaves you in a state of disbelief, wondering what more you can do to move the needle and reclaim your life.

The self doubt and desperation begins to consume you.

Nothing else exists in your life except trying to find a job. You barely acknowledge your family or friends because you're consumed with finding a job that pays the bills. A new position becomes your Great White Whale and you turn into a pathological Ahab on the hunt to find it.

With every attempt, you get oh so close, only for the oceanic beast to dive deep in the murky water and taunt you with its escape.

Foiled again.

Laying in bed at night, you torture yourself replaying the game over and over again wondering what more you could have done and how you need to try something new tomorrow.

Seemingly, nothing works and you're nothing more than a life raft bobbing on vast expanse of a job market which only wants to swallow you and drown your once promising career.

There isn't much more that you can be doing.

But, you try, you compete and, ultimately, you fail. Day after day for months and years on end. You want to give up, but the moment you stop paddling, the game up is up.

Keep doing what you're doing. It isn't fun and, at times, it feels cruel and an unfair. Those are the shakes.

You don't have to like it, you just have to survive it.

BELIEVE IN YOURSELF AS MUCH AS I BELIEVE IN YOU!

comments.commentText: The labor market is complex but we must try our best to relocate. If the strategy initially applied is not working, we must rethink and make changes, no matter how small, without losing the essence that each of us has, giving up is not an option.
